item.title: State of Georgia Personalized Medicine Awareness Day
item.description:
Morehouse School of Medicine, Louis W. Sullivan National Center for Primary Care
(720 Westview Dr SW Atlanta, GA 30310)
Thursday, September 1, 2011, 1 – 4 p.m.

Join the ACTSI and its partners, Morehouse School of Medicine, Iverson Genetic Diagnostics, and Georgia Bio in celebrating the first-ever Personalized Medicine Awareness Day in Georgia on September 1. To mark the occasion, a half-day program will be held at MSM featuring Governor Nathan Deal, a keynote address by Leroy Hood, MD, Ph.D., a pioneer in biotechnology and genomics, and a panel discussion involving scientists from MSM, Emory and Georgia Tech exploring advances in personalized medicine and Georgia’s leadership in this innovative healthcare research.

item.title: Emory Libraries at AJC Decatur Book Festival
item.description:
Corner E. Ponce de Leon and Clairemont
Downtown Decatur 30030
Saturday, September 3 – Sunday, September 4, 2011

Check out the Emory authors' book-signing schedule here: bit.ly…. Join us at the AJC Decatur Book Festival on September 3 and 4! Twenty Emory-affiliated authors – faculty, staff and distinguished alumni – have been invited to participate in the festival by giving readings and serving on panels. Many of those authors, plus a few more, will visit our huge tent to sign their books. And we’ll have tons of books for sale, courtesy of our campus Barnes & Noble bookstore! Look for our tent at the corner of East Ponce de Leon and Clairemont, facing the square.

Schedules for book signings and Emory Stage festival-wide authors will be posted at the Emory Libraries tent, so make us your first stop when you get to the festival.

Emory Libraries is proud to be a Gold-Level sponsor this year. We’ll even have our own Emory Stage, at the Decatur Presbyterian Church, where you can hear many of the festival's authors lecture or read from their works.

A few of the many Emory authors and their new or recent books:

-Joshilyn Jackson, creative writing instructor, author of “Backseat Saints” and the forthcoming “A Grown-Up Kind of Pretty” and a contributor to “Don’t Quit Your Day Job: Acclaimed Authors and the Day Jobs They Quit.”

-M.L. Malcolm, distinguished alumna and author of “Heart of Deception.”

-Allen Tullos, American studies professor in Emory’s Graduate Institute of Liberal Arts and author of “Alabama Getaway: The Political Imaginary and the Heart of Dixie.”

-Sally Wolff-King, English professor and author of “Ledgers of History: William Faulkner, an Almost Forgotten Friendship, and an Antebellum Plantation Diary.”

-Kevin Young, curator of literary collections at Emory’s Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library (MARBL), creative writing professor, and author of “Ardency” and the anthology “Best American Poetry 2011.”

Department/Organization: Emory Libraries
Event Open To: All
Cost: Free
More info: www.decaturbookfestival.com…

item.title: Dance in Progress, Anna Leo
item.description:
Dance Studio, Schwartz Center for Performing Arts
1700 N. Decatur Rd.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Tuesday, September 6, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

An intimate movement series uncovering the architecture, process, and findings of faculty choreography at Emory University.

This series will be an ongoing sharing of various stages of the choreographic process. Choreographers may present after performances, sharing their findings and illuminations; or while they are living the dynamic, chaotic process of crafting and discovering; or during the initial, impulsive cultivation of concepts, thoughts, images, and movement.

All events will be on Tuesday evenings at 7:30 p.m. in the Dance Studio in the Schwartz Center for Performing Arts. Free and open to the public.

September 6 - Anna Leo
September 20 - George Staib
September 27 - Kyle Abraham, Guest Artist
October 4 - Lori Teague
November 1 - Gregory Catellier

item.title: Halle Speaker Series: Indonesian Ambassador Dr. Dino Patti Djalal
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall, Third Floor
571 South Kilgo Circle
Atlanta, Georgia 30322
Wednesday, September 7, 2011, 4:15 – 5:45 p.m.



Faculty Hosts: Steve Everett, Vince Cornell, and Rick Doner

Dr. Dino Patti Djalal is the Indonesian ambassador to the United States and a speechwriter, youth activist, and academic. He was previously a presidential spokesperson for President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono.

Djalal joined the Department of Foreign Affairs in Indonesia in 1987 with posts to Dili, East Timor; London; and Washington, D.C., before he was appointed director for North American Affairs in 2002. In the early years of his career, as assistant to Director General for Political Affairs Wiryono Sastrohandoyo, his work involved the Cambodian conflict, the settlement of the Moro conflict in the Phillipines, the South China Sea disputes, and the East Timor conflict.

Djalal holds a doctorate from the London School of Economics and Political Science, where he studied preventive diplomacy.

This event is free and open to the public.

Event Title: Achieving Confluence in the 21st Century: How Indonesia and the United States Can Work Together
Speaker/Presenter: Indonesian Ambassador Dr. Dino Patti Djalal

item.title: "Double Indemnity," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, September 7, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Billy Wilder; Paramount, 1944) (1.37:1, 107 min.) Adapted by Wilder and Raymond Chandler from a novel by James M. Cain; cinematography by John Seitz; music by Miklós Rózsa; starring Fred MacMurray, Barbara Stanwyck, Edward G. Robinson.

This most famous of films noir was inspired by an equally notorious 1927 murder-for-insurance-money case that resulted in the sensational news photo of the electrocution of Queens, New York housewife Ruth Snyder. Writer James M. Cain serialized his novel in 1935 and turned it into a script the same year. It immediately generated interest at virtually every studio, but each withdrew their bids after Hays Office strong man Joseph Breen sent out an extremely intimidating letter. In 1943, writer-director Wilder went for it anyway and brought in hard-boiled writer Raymond Chandler to help him. The writing team never jelled, but Wilder came to see the value of Chandler's dialogue, building as it did to one cinema's most devastating endings.

Emory Event Topic: Arts
Department/Organization: Film Studies
Series: Emory Cinematheque Series
Event Open To: All
Venue: Room 205
Building/Room: White Hall
Contact Phone: 404-727-6761
More info: www.arts.emory.edu

item.title: Family and Friends Day 2011
item.description:
Emory University School of Law , Gambrell Hall , 1301 Clifton Road , Atlanta, GA 30322
Friday, September 9, 2011, 8:30 a.m. – 4 p.m.

We look forward to seeing you!
At Family and Friends Day 2011, attendees experience a day in the life of an Emory Law student. You will hear from Emory Law Interim Dean Robert Schapiro, as well the Vice Dean and other Law School supporting divisions. Guests and their students will eat lunch together and sit in on an actual law class. All are invited to a reception at the end of the day.

This is a great opportunity to learn about what goes on during the first year of law school. Last year, more than 100 family and friends attended this annual event.

Schedule
Check-in and a light, continental breakfast will occur from 8:30–9 a.m. in room 1E of Gambrell Hall. The program begins at 9 a.m. with a welcome from our Family and Friends Chair Rob Kaufman 79L, followed by a presentation and Q&A with Interim Dean Robert Schapiro and Vice Dean Robert Ahdieh.

The morning continues with presentations from our Student Services, Career Services divisions and Development and Alumni Relations. Then, after a short break, a Professor will lead the group through a sample constitutional law class. At 12:30 p.m., you will join your students for lunch, and then attend an actual first-year Torts class with them in the afternoon. The day concludes at 3:30 p.m. with a reception on Bacardi Plaza.

Lunch
Box lunches are provided for all guests and their student at 12:30 p.m. If you have special dietary needs, please contact Cassandra Blackburn so that we may try to accommodate your request - crblack@emory.edu.

Attire
Similar to what your students wear to class, casual/comfortable dress is appropriate.

Cost
$25 per guest (includes breakfast, lunch and afternoon reception). Only family members and friends need to register - event is free to Emory Law students.

Parking
All day parking in Lowergate Deck (visitors parking deck) is only $12. Emory School of Law/Gambrell Hall is short distance away.

More info: www.alumniconnections.com…
item.xCal:location: Emory University School of Law , Gambrell Hall , 1301 Clifton Road , Atlanta, GA 30322
item.xCal:description:
We look forward to seeing you! At Family and Friends Day 2011, attendees experience a day in the life of an Emory Law student. You will hear from Emory Law Interim Dean Robert Schapiro, as well the Vice Dean and other Law School supporting divisions. Guests and their students will eat lunch together and sit in on an actual law class. All are invited to a reception at the end of the day.
This is a great opportunity to learn about what goes on during the first year of law school. Last year, more than 100 family and friends attended this annual event.
Schedule Check-in and a light, continental breakfast will occur from 8:30–9 a.m. in room 1E of Gambrell Hall. The program begins at 9 a.m. with a welcome from our Family and Friends Chair Rob Kaufman 79L, followed by a presentation and Q&A with Interim Dean Robert Schapiro and Vice Dean Robert Ahdieh.
The morning continues with presentations from our Student Services, Career Services divisions and Development and Alumni Relations. Then, after a short break, a Professor will lead the group through a sample constitutional law class. At 12:30 p.m., you will join your students for lunch, and then attend an actual first-year Torts class with them in the afternoon. The day concludes at 3:30 p.m. with a reception on Bacardi Plaza.
Lunch Box lunches are provided for all guests and their student at 12:30 p.m. If you have special dietary needs, please contact Cassandra Blackburn so that we may try to accommodate your request - crblack@emory.edu.
Attire Similar to what your students wear to class, casual/comfortable dress is appropriate.
Cost $25 per guest (includes breakfast, lunch and afternoon reception). Only family members and friends need to register - event is free to Emory Law students.
Parking All day parking in Lowergate Deck (visitors parking deck) is only $12. Emory School of Law/Gambrell Hall is short distance away.

item.title: Artful Stories: The Runaway Mummy
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Third Floor Galleries
Saturday, September 10, 2011, 10 – 11 a.m.

“Once there was a little mummy who wanted to run away. “If you run away,” said Mother Mummy, “I will get you! For you are my rotten little mummy!” So begins The Runaway Mummy, a clever parody of a popular children’s story. Children ages 3-5 and their accompanying adults will hear this charming story while in the presence of the Old Kingdom mummy, then move to the studio to “mummify” a toy.
This program is free but a reservation is required by calling 404.727.0519.

Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: Reception for "The Mind's Eye" Photo Exhibit by Myron McGhee
item.description:
Chace Gallery, Schwartz Center for Performing Arts
1700 N. Decatur Rd
Atlanta, GA 30322
Sunday, September 11, 2011, 12:30 – 2:30 p.m.

The reception will provide a time for people to come together to view "The Mind's Eye" exhibit, and to reflect on the role of the arts in peacemaking. At 1:00pm, there will be remarks by Juana Clem McGhee, Curator; Myron McGhee, Photographer; and Geshe Dadul Namgyal of Drepung Loseling Monastery.

"The Mind's Eye" is an exhibit of Myron McGhee's photographs of Tibetan monks painting sand mandalas at Emory University in Atlanta, Georgia.

While the monks focus their attention on the artistic elements of creating the sand mandala, they also devote their minds to meditation for the healing of the earth. Observing their sacred practice, our eyes are drawn to the exquisite beauty of their art, and our minds are inspired by their religious devotion.

This collection of photographs will be on exhibit at various venues on Emory's campus throughout the 2011-2012 academic year. The exhibit is curated by Juana Clem McGhee and made possible through generous support from the university and other organizations in the Atlanta area.

To view exhibits online, go to www.myron.smugmug.com…

Department/Organization: Center for Creativity & Arts, Center for Ethics, Emory Alumni Association, Emory Tibet Partnership, Emory University Program in Science and Society, Institute of Liberal Arts, Middle Eastern and South Asian Studies, Religion Department, Religious Life
Event Open To: All
Meeting Organizer/Sponsor: Drepung Loseling Monastery, Mystical Arts of Tibet, Showcase Photo and Video, Toco Hill Picture Framing
Venue: Chace Gallery
Building/Room: Donna & Marvin Schwartz Center for Performing Arts
Cost: Free
More info: www.creativity.emory.edu

item.title: Lecture: Life and Death in Late Old Kingdom Egypt
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Monday, September 12, 2011, 7:30 – 8:30 p.m.

The Carlos Museum's Old Kingdom mummy comes from a time at the end of the pinnacle of ancient Egyptian civilization, an era of tremendous change that would forever change life along the Nile. In a lecture titled "Life and Death in Late Old Kingdom Egypt," Dr. Peter Lacovara, Senior Curator of Ancient Egyptian, Nubian, and Near Eastern Art, will introduce the period and the exhibition and explain the significance of this restored mummy.

Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: Decalogue Lecture: The Bioethical Future--Some Jewish Thoughts on Reproductive Ethics
item.description:
Emory University School of Law, Tull Auditorium
Tuesday, September 13, 2011, 7:30 – 9 p.m.

Michael J. Broyde, professor of law and Senior Fellow at the Center for the Study of Law and Religion, was ordained as a rabbi by Yeshiva University and is a member (dayan) of the Beth Din of America, the largest Jewish law court in America. He will highlight several morally difficult questions created by advances in modern science, including genetic cloning in humans and plants, and offer a Jewish law response as well as religiously informed public policy recommendations.

item.title: Choreographing a Life's Landscape: Anna Halprin's Dances in the Environment
item.description:
Presentation Room, Oxford Road Building
1390 Oxford Road
Atlanta, GA 30322
Tuesday, September 13, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

The oldest living, and working, contemporary dance artist in America, Anna Halprin, continues to shape dance events that challenge our perceptions of dance, the environment, the aging body and their intimate connections. Dr. Janice Ross, Halprin's biographer, explores the dances in nature the 91-year-old Halprin continues to make as she traces the intersections of her work and that of her late husband, the landscape architect Lawrence Halprin, with nature and disappearance. Co-sponsored by the Department of Environmental Studies

Wednesday, September 14, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Robert Siodmak; Universal, 1946) (1.37:1, 103 min.) Produced by Mark Hellinger; written by Anthony Veiller (and John Huston) from a story by Ernest Hemingway; cinematography by Elwood Bredell, music by Miklós Rózsa; starring Burt Lancaster, Ava Gardner, Edmond O'Brien.

According to Hemingway, his shortest of short stories (3,000 words) "probably had more left out of it than anything I ever wrote." Producer Hellinger and director Siodmak took the writer's story about two gunmen who go into a diner looking for a boxer named Swede and built a complicated flashback narrative that explains what Hemingway "left out." German émigré Siodmak would become heavily associated with the film noir cycle, incorporating elements of old school Expressionist lighting for modern American ends. Yet another film on the National Registry, The Killers inspired a remake by Don Siegel starring Lee Marvin, Angie Dickinson and Ronald Reagan, as well as a nearly shot-for-shot version of Siodmak's opening by Soviet director Andrei Tarkovsky that as a 19 minute student film effectively turns Siodmak's film back into the unanswered question of Hemingway's original.

item.title: “Reconsidering the ‘German Jew’ in America: Images and Identities”
item.description:
Marcus Hillel Center at Emory University, 735 Gatewood Road
Sunday, September 18, 2011

This symposium brings together a number of scholars, from US and international institutions as well as from Emory, to examine the category “German Jew” in the United States, looking both at the extent to which Jewish immigrants from German-speaking lands understood themselves as “German” and the extent to which non-Jewish immigrants from the same regions saw them as such. Participants will also consider how these identities and images changed over time, how Jews and non-Jews negotiated these multiple and overlapping identities, and what this might tell us about the larger dynamics of German ethnic identity and ethnic identities more broadly in the United States. Cosponsored by the Claus M. Halle Institute for Global Learning, the Laney Graduate School, the Departments of History and German Studies, and the European Studies Program.

item.title: Make Your Own Mummy Workshop for Children
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Tate Room
Sunday, September 18, 2011, 2 – 4 p.m.

Make Your Own Mummy Workshop for Children
In addition to mummifying humans, the ancient Egyptians also mummified animals including birds, crocodiles, cats, and fish. In this two-part workshop, children will visit the galleries to examine animal and human mummies. Then they will "mummify" a fish. They will re-create natron, the ancient salt used by the Egyptians to dehydrate the body, and seal their fish in the mixture. In the second session on October 2nd, they will anoint the mummified body with scented oils and practice the art of wrapping the mummy with strips of linen. Ages 8-12. $12 for Museum members; $15 for non-members. Pre-registration is required by calling 404.727.0519.

Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: Carlos Reads Book Club
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Board Room
Monday, September 19, 2011, 7:30 – 9 p.m.

A dominant theme in Chinua Achebe’s writing is the problem of power and authority in Africa, nowhere more so than in his 1964 Arrow of God. Born in 1930 in southeastern Nigeria among the Igbo, Achebe lived through the most momentous period in modern Nigerian history: the ending of colonialism and independence in 1960, followed by the disastrous 1967 Biafran War, which Achebe supported.

Igbo history offered Achebe a way of thinking about power in Africa: its making and daily enactments; its legitimacy and social basis; and particularly its abuse. Arrow of God affords the reader an uncommon insight into African history and culture, and invites us to consider anew enduring themes in the human condition. Over two Monday evenings, September 19 and October 3, Dr. Clifton Crais, Professor of History and African Studies at Emory, will lead readers though this powerful book.
Fee: $25 for Carlos Museum members; $35 for non-members. Fee includes cost of the book.

item.title: "Lady From Shanghai," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, September 21, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Orson Welles; Columbia, 1947) (1.37:1, 87 min.) Adapted by Welles from Sherwood King's novel by Raymond Chandler; cinematography by Charles Lawton Jr., Rudolph Maté; starring Rita Hayworth, Orson Welles, Everett Sloane.

In need of a fast $50,000, Welles called wife Rita Hayworth's boss—Columbia's Harry Cohn—and offered to write, direct and star in a picture for that sum. When Cohn asked what it would be about, Welles picked a paperback from the rack next to the payphone and read him the title. If Welles and Cohn made a single other decision that met with each other’s approval history doesn't record it. Welles' location-shot film was radically trimmed—by some accounts by as much as an hour—to placate Cohn's famously impatient butt and decades later Welles still winced at its opening. But the director’s greatest objection was to Heinz Roemheld's overly obvious score. Still, both Cohn and Welles were ultimately in complete agreement about the final film: neither liked it. While, it’s hall of mirrors shoot out remains one Welles' most famous achievements, Welles always insisted what was cut from the rest of the funhouse was still better.

item.title: Atlanta Music Festival - From the Poet: Words with Music
item.description:
Jones Room, 311 Woodruff Library
540 Asbury Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Thursday, September 22, 2011, 12 – 1:30 p.m.

Creativity Conversation with Pearl Cleage: Notes on History, Music, and Literature

As part of the Atlanta Music Festival, Vice President and Secretary Rosemary Magee will conduct a creativity conversation with Pearl Cleage, acclaimed poet, novelist, and playwright. They will consider the imaginative interplay between various forms of artistic expression within the context of major historical events in Atlanta and across the country. As in the other Creativity Conversations held over the last four years with influential thinkers, their talk will range widely across poetry, fiction, music, and history, including insights on the creative process and the power of the imagination.

item.title: Office of LGBT Life 20th Anniversary Dinner
item.description:
Dobbs University Center - Winship Ballroom , 605 Asbury Circle , Atlanta, GA 30322
Friday, September 23, 2011, 7 – 9 p.m.

Emory University was the ninth campus in the country to offer support services for LGBT students. Emory is now classified by the LGBT Friendly Campus Climate Index as a Five Star rated university (the highest rating possible). Please join fellow alumni, campus administrators, faculty, staff and students to celebrate 20 years of advocacy, support, and education.

We’ll have special guests in attendance who were integral to the office’s founding. Dinner is $50 per person and all proceeds will support Emory’s Office of LGBT Life.

You can also support the Office of LGBT Life’s 20th anniversary programs and activities by being a dinner host! (Admission to the dinner is included in your host level donation.)

Host Levels
Supporter - $100
Advocate - $250
Leader - $500
Mentor - $1000
Champion - $2500
Lord Dooley’s Queer Friend - $5000

More info: www.alumniconnections.com…

item.title: Barkley Forum Alumni Reunion
item.description:
Miller Ward Alumni House
Sunday, September 25, 2011, 10 a.m. – 12 p.m.

The Barkley Forum is celebrating 60 successful years this September, in conjunction with Emory University’s Homecoming Weekend celebrations, with events and activities for all of our alumni. You are invited to attend a Barkley Forum reunion brunch held at the Miller-Ward Alumni House on Sunday, September 25, 2011 at 10 am. Registration information to follow.

This special event celebrates not only your history as alumni of the BF but also celebrates The Barkley Forum Endowment fundraising effort, led by co-chairs Lilly Correa 73C and Cully Clark 65C 68G. The Endowment is the way to guarantee not only the future of Emory debate but also the continued support of our debate education and outreach programs across the country. Many thanks to those of you who have supported the Barkley Forum Endowment already. If you have yet to make a gift or pledge of support, please click here (linked to: www.emory.edu/give).

Sponsoring department(s): Barkley Forum
Event Open To: Alumni
Event website: www.alumniconnections.com…
Contact Name: Melissa Wade
Contact Email: mwade@emory.edu
More info: www.alumniconnections.com…

item.title: McDonald Lecture Series by James Carroll–Jesus: Solitude or Solidarity?
item.description:
Glenn Auditorium
1660 North Decatur Road NE
Atlanta, GA 30307
Monday, September 26, 2011, 7 – 9 p.m.



Award-winning author, Boston Globe columnist and former Catholic priest James Carroll is Emory University's 2011 McDonald Family Chair on the Life and Teachings of Jesus and their Impact on Culture. In this role, he will present a series of four McDonald lectures during the fall of 2011 arranged around the theme "Jesus Against Himself: From Itinerant Galilean to Christ of God and Back Again." These lectures will discuss how the fundamentals of Christian belief in Jesus are challenged by history and criticism.

"Jesus: Solitude or Solidarity?" is the second presentation in the four-lecture series. Carroll explores the social context of Jesus' time—Roman occupation, Hellenization, Judaism in flux—and his role in it, with particular attention to the place of women. How was Jesus a religious genius and a master of community organizing? What's the relationship of God's Oneness to the beloved community, the relationship between religion and politics?

Photograph by Patricia Pingree.

Emory Event Topic: Lectures & Meetings
Building/Room: Glenn Memorial UMC
Event Open To: All
Contact Name: Lauren McCrary
Contact Email: candleralum@emory.edu
Contact Phone: 404.727.6352
Region: *Metro Atlanta*

item.title: Conversations with author James Carroll: Jesus: Solitude or Solidarity?
item.description:
815 Houston Mill Road
Atlanta, GA 30329
Tuesday, September 27, 2011, 11 a.m. – 1 p.m.



Space is limited, please follow this link to register for one or all lectures in the series: tinyurl.com…

Join author James Carroll for lunch and conversation on:

Jesus: Solitude or Solidarity?
In this lecture the social context of Jesus' milieu (Roman occupation, Hellenization, Judaism in flux, etc.) and his role in it are explored. Particular attention is paid to the place of women. The religious genius of Jesus is discussed as well His ministry of community organizing. From God’s oneness to the beloved community. Politics and religion.

This conversation is part of the series:
Jesus Against Himself: From Itinerant Galilean to Christ of God and Back Again.

item.title: Dance in Progress, Kyle Abraham, Guest Artist
item.description:
Dance Studio, Schwartz Center for Performing Arts
1700 N. Decatur Rd.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Tuesday, September 27, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

An intimate movement series uncovering the architecture, process, and findings of faculty choreography at Emory University.

This series will be an ongoing sharing of various stages of the choreographic process. Choreographers may present after performances, sharing their findings and illuminations; or while they are living the dynamic, chaotic process of crafting and discovering; or during the initial, impulsive cultivation of concepts, thoughts, images, and movement.

All events will be on Tuesday evenings at 7:30 p.m. in the Dance Studio in the Schwartz Center for Performing Arts. Free and open to the public.

item.title: "Sorry, Wrong Number," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, September 28, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Anatole Litvak, Paramount, 1948) (1.37:1, 89 min.) Produced by Hal Wallis; adapted by Lucille Fletcher from her radio play; cinematography by Sol Polito; music by Franz Waxman; starring Barbara Stanwyck, Burt Lancaster. Print courtesy of the Academy Film Archive.

Sorry, Wrong Number began as a hit 1943 radio drama built around the single role of a bed-ridden heiress who overhears plans for her murder on her phone. The role was initially played and then revived seven times by Mercury Theater's Agnes Moorehead. But Paramount gave Barbara Stanwyck the job of bringing the part to the screen, where it earned her an Academy Award nomination. Two years later she was doing it on radio too. Lucille Fletcher's screenplay used flashbacks to open up her own radio drama’s real time/one location /one role conceit. Interestingly, the film’s team of first-string pros included composer Franz Waxman instead of the man who supplied the music for the radio drama, Fletcher's then husband, Bernard Herrmann.

item.title: Make Your Own Mummy Workshop for Children
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Tate Room
Sunday, October 2, 2011, 2 – 4 p.m.

Make Your Own Mummy Workshop for Children
This is the second part of a two part workshop.
In addition to mummifying humans, the ancient Egyptians also mummified animals including birds, crocodiles, cats, and fish. In this two-part workshop, children will visit the galleries to examine animal and human mummies. Then they will "mummify" a fish. They will re-create natron, the ancient salt used by the Egyptians to dehydrate the body, and seal their fish in the mixture. In the second session on October 2nd, they will anoint the mummified body with scented oils and practice the art of wrapping the mummy with strips of linen. Ages 8-12. $12 for Museum members; $15 for non-members. Pre-registration is required by calling 404.727.0519.

Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: Creativity Conversation with Deborah Lipstadt and Rosemary Magee
item.description:
Jones Room, 311 Woodruff Library
540 Asbury Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Monday, October 3, 2011, 4 p.m.

What does creativity mean in a historical context? How does the imagination inform scholarship? Come hear Rosemary Magee and Deborah Lipstadt discuss these and other questions as they explore the curious relationship between history and creativity. They will also be discussing Lipstadt’s latest book, "The Eichmann Trial." The book discusses the capture of an SS lieutenant colonel in 1960, his trial, and the effect of the survivors' courtroom testimony of their experiences on the world's understanding of the Holocaust. Deborah Lipstadt is the Dorot Professor of Modern Jewish and Holocaust Studies at Emory who is known around the world for her work on the Holocaust and has served on the United States Holocaust Memorial Council. Rosemary Magee serves as Vice-President and Secretary of the University. She has led creativity conversations with a wide range of scholars, scientists, and artists.

item.title: Carlos Reads Book Club
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum, Board Room
Monday, October 3, 2011, 7:30 – 9 p.m.

A dominant theme in Chinua Achebe’s writing is the problem of power and authority in Africa, nowhere more so than in his 1964 Arrow of God. Born in 1930 in southeastern Nigeria among the Igbo, Achebe lived through the most momentous period in modern Nigerian history: the ending of colonialism and independence in 1960, followed by the disastrous 1967 Biafran War, which Achebe supported.

Igbo history offered Achebe a way of thinking about power in Africa: its making and daily enactments; its legitimacy and social basis; and particularly its abuse. Arrow of God affords the reader an uncommon insight into African history and culture, and invites us to consider anew enduring themes in the human condition. Dr. Clifton Crais, Professor of History and African Studies at Emory, will lead readers though this powerful book.
Fee: $25 for Carlos Museum members; $35 for non-members. Fee includes cost of the book.

item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Tuesday, October 4, 2011, 12 – 1 p.m.

Dr. Jessica Stephenson, Curator of African Art, kicks off the Yam Festival with a talk about the yam festivals of Ghana and Nigeria and the importance of the yam in the ritual and daily life of the people of West Africa. After her talk, dancers and drummers from Giwayen Mata will perform and lead a yam festival procession to the Emory Farmers Market where farmers will offer many varieties of locally grown yams and sweet potatoes.

item.title: The Emory Big Draw
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Wednesday, October 5, 2011, 10 a.m. – 4 p.m.

The Big Draw is an international movement that began in Britain and is now held throughout the month of October each year. In cities across the U.S., people are encouraged to slow their hectic pace, pick up a pencil, and draw.
Try contour drawings, explore light and shadow with a Classical sculpture, make a cubist drawing inspired by African masks at the Carlos, sketch landscapes and architecture on the Quad, or draw from live models and giant still life arrangements in Asbury Circle. Bring your own materials or pick up a sketchpad and pencil at the Carlos Museum or Dobbs University Center. This program is co-sponsored by the Center for Creativity and the Arts, the Program in Visual Arts, and Wonderful Wednesdays.

item.title: "Pulp Fiction," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 208
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, October 5, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Quentin Tarantino; Miramax, 1994) (2.35:1, 154 min.) Written by Quentin Tarantino; cinematography by Andrzej Sekula; Starring John Travolta, Samuel L. Jackson, Tim Roth, Amanda Plummer, Bruce Willis, Ving Rhames, Uma Thurman, Rosanna Arquette, Steve Buscemi, Christopher Walken, Harvey Keitel, Quentin Tarantino.

Former video store clerk Quentin Tarantino's sophomore effort, with its four intertwined, non-linear narratives, its sudden, explosive jolts of heart-gagging violence, its riffing, "American gutter-rant" dialogue and its endless stream of pop culture references, won him the Palme d'Or at Cannes. When Columbia TriStar backed out of bankrolling it because production head Mike Medavoy determined it "too demented," it ended up at Miramax, only months earlier acquired by Disney. The picture made back its $8 million production costs opening weekend, with worldwide grosses to date approaching a quarter billion.

Jackson, Tim Roth, Amanda Plummer, Bruce Willis, Ving Rhames, Uma Thurman, Rosanna Arquette, Steve Buscemi, Christopher Walken, Harvey Keitel, Quentin Tarantino.
Former video store clerk Quentin Tarantino's sophomore effort, with its four intertwined, non-linear narratives, its sudden, explosive jolts of heart-gagging violence, its riffing, "American gutter-rant" dialogue and its endless stream of pop culture references, won him the Palme d'Or at Cannes. When Columbia TriStar backed out of bankrolling it because production head Mike Medavoy determined it "too demented," it ended up at Miramax, only months earlier acquired by Disney. The picture made back its $8 million production costs opening weekend, with worldwide grosses to date approaching a quarter billion.

item.title: Richard Bausch, Colloquium
item.description:
N301 Callaway Center
537 Kilgo Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Thursday, October 6, 2011, 2:30 – 3:30 p.m.

Fiction writer. He is the author of eleven novels and eight collections of stories, including the novels "Rebel Powers," "Violence," "Good Evening Mr. & Mrs. America and All the Ships at Sea," "In the Night Season,” "Hello to the Cannibals," "Thanksgiving Night" and "Peace;" and the story collections "Spirits," "The Fireman’s Wife," "Rare & Endangered Species," "Someone to Watch Over Me," "The Selected Stories of Richard Bausch," "Wives & Lovers," and "Something Is Out There." He has won two National Magazine Awards, a Guggenheim Fellowship, and a Lila-Wallace Reader's Digest Fund Writer's Award, the Award of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, and The 2004 PEN/Malamud Award for Excellence in the Short Story.

item.title: Yam Festival: A Conversation with Scott Peacock: The Sweet Potato in Southern Culture
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Thursday, October 6, 2011, 7:30 – 8:30 p.m.

At the beginning of the twentieth century, sweet potatoes were one of the most important crops in the United States. In the South, their popularity led to their integration into popular culture-- from blues music to Sweet Potato Queens. Renowned Southern chef and author Scott Peacock will share taste memories of sweet potatoes from his own Alabama youth and the stories he has gleaned from others in his years of oral history gathering. He will prepare and share the simple pleasure of slow-baked "cured" potatoes, rich with their own syrup and served cold. Bring your own memory or recipe to serve as part of the evening's conversation.

item.description:
Zoo Atlanta, 800 Cherokee Ave SE , Atlanta, GA 30315, www.zooatlanta.org
Sunday, October 9, 2011, 9:30 a.m. – 3:30 p.m.

Lions, Tigers, and Bears...and Eagles!!



Join the Emory Alumni Association for Emory Day at Zoo Atlanta , as the Eagles descend on the local zoo for a day of wild fun! As you don your safari hats to explore all that Zoo Atlanta has to offer, be sure to check in at our exclusive Emory "base camp."

Emory alumni, students, parents, faculty/staff, and friends will enjoy discounted admission to the zoo, refreshments at the Emory base camp, kids’ activities, animal shows, and a host of other special features. item.title: African Udu Drum Workshop for Children
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Tate Room
Sunday, October 9, 2011, 2 – 4 p.m.

Drums and drumming are important throughout Africa and are often a part of festivals such as the “new yam festivals” of Nigeria and Ghana. Along with special dishes made from yams, these harvest festival include parades led by drummers playing udu drums. Made of clay, the udu is fashioned in the shape of a gourd with a hole in it. It is played by quickly hitting the large hole, producing a bass sound. In this workshop, ceramic artist Ana Vizurraga will teach children to make their own udu. Ages 8 and up. $12 for Museum members; $15 for non-members. Pre-registration is required by calling 404.727.0519.

item.title: Fall Congregational Conference–The Art of Preaching in the 21st Century
item.description:
Candler School of Theology
1531 Dickey Dr NE
Atlanta, GA 30322-1003
Monday, October 10 – Wednesday, October 12, 2011



To register and for more information, visit tinyurl.com…. Preaching today is not—and should not be—the same as it was yesterday. Yes, the gospel message is always counter-cultural to a degree, but great preachers realize that the message is never heard in a vacuum—environment and culture impact the hearing of proclamation. Preaching today must make the connection between the claims of Christian faith and the world in which we live.

Join seven nationally acclaimed preachers at Emory University’s Candler School of Theology in Atlanta this October 11-12 and learn The Art of Preaching in the 21st Century. Each day’s schedule will include worship services, workshops, and discussion sessions. Sermons and lectures will be delivered by:

Tom Long, Bandy Professor of Preaching
Candler School of Theology, Atlanta, GA

Otis Moss III, Senior Pastor
Trinity United Church of Christ, Chicago, IL

Teresa Fry Brown, Professor of Homiletics
Candler School of Theology, Atlanta, GA

James C. Howell, Senior Pastor
Myers Park United Methodist Church, Charlotte, NC.

Anna Carter Florence, Peter Marshall Associate Professor of Preaching and Worship
Columbia Theological Seminary, Decatur, GA

Gary V. Simpson, Senior Pastor
Concord Baptist Church, Brooklyn, NY

Cláudio Carvalhaes, Assistant Professor of Worship and Preaching
Louisville Presbyterian Seminary, Louisville, KY

P. Alice Rogers, Assistant Professor in the Practice of Congregational Leadership
Candler School of Theology, Atlanta, GA

item.description:
Candler School of Theology, Emory University
Monday, October 10, 2011, 5:30 – 9 p.m.

This year marks your 5, 10, or 25 anniversary of your graduation from Candler! Come celebrate and share during a time of reunion on Monday, October 10, 2011.

Here is what the evening will include:
5:30–7:00 p.m. Candler Fall Reunion Dinner Candler School of Theology
7:00–8:00 p.m. Worship: Otis Moss, III preaching Cannon Chapel
8:00–9:00 p.m. Dessert with your Class Cannon Chapel
All reunion classes will gather together for dinner with Dean Love, move to worship with Otis Moss, III, and then have dessert with your specific class. The cost for the evening is $25 per person, $50.00 per couple.
As part of your reunion, Candler’s Office of Lifelong Learning will be sponsoring the annual Fall Congregational Conference from October 10–12, 2011. Alice Rogers – to learn The Art of Preaching in the 21st Century. To register for that event and for more information, visit tinyurl.com… .

The Emory Conference Center and Hotel has rooms blocked for this occassion if you require overnight accommodations. You can choose to stay at the Emory Conference Center Hotel at the rate of $149.00 per night, or the Emory Inn at the rate of $76.00 per night.

item.title: Theater of War
item.description:
Springer Opera House
103 Tenth Street
Columbus, GA 31901
Monday, October 10, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

Theater of War is an innovative project that presents readings of Ancient Greek plays – Sophocles’ Ajax and Philoctetes – as a catalyst for town hall discussions about the challenges faced by service members, veterans, and their families and caregivers today. Using Sophocles’ plays to forge a common vocabulary for openly discussing the impact of war on individuals, families and communities, these events will be aimed at generating compassion and understanding between diverse audiences. Translated by Bryan Doerries. Directed by John Ammerman. Produced by Phyllis Kaufman. Made possible by the generous support of the Stavros Niarchos Foundation in collaboration with the United Service Organizations.

item.title: Ethics at the Movies- "Disabled but Able to Rock"
item.description:
Center for Ethics- Room 102
Wednesday, October 12, 2011, 6 p.m.

Disabled But Able To Rock follows the life of Betsy Goodrich, a high-functioning autistic woman and her singing superhero alter ego, Danger Woman. As Danger Woman, Betsy fights the Tri-phobes: Race-ophobia; Homophobia; and Disable-phobia, with her high-octave voice and her eccentric group of friends from the underground subculture of Atlanta. Danger Woman has made a cultural impact in her hometown by assisting in the founding of the comic convention DragonCon, recording 6 full albums, and performing at various cultural events. Her exploits even inspired the rock band, The Aqua Bats, to write a song based on her titled “Danger Woman.”

Emory Event Topic: Arts, Religion & Ethics
School: Emory University

Audience: All

item.title: CNN Dialogues - Social Media: Are We Living in the Now?
item.description:
The Ray Charles Performing Arts Center of Morehouse College , 830 Westview Drive, NW, Atlanta, GA 30314
Wednesday, October 12, 2011, 7 – 8:30 p.m.

On behalf of CNN, the James Weldon Johnson Institute for the Study of Race and Difference of Emory University, and the National Center For Civil and Human Rights, you are invited to attend the second open forum of CNN Dialogues on Wednesday, October 12 at 7:00 pm at The Ray Charles Performing Arts Center of Morehouse College.

CNN DIALOGUES: Social Media: Are We Living in the Now? Living in the Age of Social Media—the Good, the Bad, and the Surprising Social media has changed the world, literally. Today, we have access to unlimited amounts of information and countless numbers of people. With this revolutionary ability to connect, are we really connecting? How does the presence of Facebook and Twitter, our smartphones and iPads, shape who we are, how we conduct business, and how we relate to each another?

On October 12, social media experts and developers from some of today’s most popular social media platforms will come together at The Ray Charles Performing Arts Center of Morehouse College to explore what it means to live in the age of social media.

This event, moderated by CNN's Don Lemon, will feature panelists:


Maggie Jackson, Author of
"Distracted: The Erosion of Attention and
the Coming Dark Age"


Randi Zuckerberg, Former Head of Marketing at
Facebook, Co-Founder & CEO, R to Z Media

Baratunde Thurston, Comedian & Blogger,
Director of Digital, The Onion

Additional panelists will be announced soon.

More info: www.alumniconnections.com…

item.title: "Detour," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, October 12, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Edgar G. Ulmer; PRC, 1945) (1.37:1, 67 min.) Screenplay and original story by Martin Goldsmith; Cinematography by Benjamin H. Kline; Starring Tom Neal, Ann Savage.

Austrian-born Edgar G. Ulmer began his film career apprenticing as a set designer on such important German films as The Golem, Metropolis and M. He entered the American film industry directing Yiddish-language films before moving on to the lowest rungs of "poverty row." Detour, perhaps his most legendary picture, was made for Producers Releasing Corporation, a company only months away from being absorbed by another independent studio associated with noir—Eagle-Lion. Though Ulmer's claims in the 1970s that he shot the film in six days for $20,000 have been debunked, the film's low budget aesthetic is gloriously on full display. But the film really belongs to its lead actress, the appropriately named Ann Savage, whose hot-cold performance ranks as the most bitter and hard-bitten of all film noir's "spider women."

Double featured with the 1950 low budget indie-production D.O.A., in which Polish-born, Hungarian-trained cinematographer-turned-director Rudolph Maté flips noir's investigation narrative by having Edmond O'Brien's Frank "soft in the belly" Bigelow track down his own killer. 83 minutes.

Emory Event Topic: Arts
Department/Organization: Film Studies
Series: Emory Cinematheque Series
Event Open To: All
Venue: Room 205
Building/Room: White Hall
Cost: Free
Contact Phone: 404-727-6761
More info: www.arts.emory.edu

item.title: Stalking: A Deadly Weapon of Power and Control
item.description:
Few Multipurpose Room G27
Thursday, October 13, 2011, 6 – 8 p.m.

Men Stopping Violence, a nationally recognized organization recently featured on CNN, will present this workshop. Participants will examine technological and other tactics stalkers use to exert power and control. Participants will then work in small groups to brainstorm strategies for community accountability for stalkers. This event is cosponsored by the Office of University-Community Partnerships.

item.title: Water Study: A Site-Specific Event
item.description:
Baker Woodlands/Source Route sculpture
Saturday, October 15, 2011, 8 p.m.

Water Study is a site-specific collaborative work created by D. Patton White, Emory dance alumnus and artistic director of Beacon Dance. The work features Emory students and members of Beacon Dance. Structured as a tour of a scientific experiment, Water Study will take the audience on a journey through the environment of the Baker Woodlands ravine where they will encounter not only the scientists, but the subjects of the experiment. What will happen when the subjects begin to respond in completely unanticipated ways?

PLEASE NOTE: The Arts at Emory Box Office is closed on the weekends. Calls made on Saturday October 15th, or Sunday October 16th for weekend reservations, should be directed to Beacon Dance at 404.377.2929.

Please note: The audience will travel on terrain of varying difficulty. Warm comfortable clothing, hiking shoes, and insect repellant are recommended. Flashlights will be provided to the audience members. Performances will take place rain or shine; please dress accordingly and bring your own umbrella.

This project is sponsored in part by a grant from the Emory College Center for Creativity and Arts.

Performances:
Sat., Oct. 15, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Sun., Oct. 16, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Mon., Oct. 17, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Tues., Oct. 18, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.
Wed., Oct. 19, 6 p.m. and 8 p.m.

item.title: 6th Annual Freshman Legacy Brunch & Pinning Ceremony
item.description:
Miller-Ward Alumni House, Governor's Hall, 815 Houston Mill Road NE, Atlanta, GA 30329
Sunday, October 16, 2011, 10:30 a.m. – 12 p.m.

You're Invited!


The Emory Alumni Association cordially invites you to the 6th Annual Freshman Legacy Brunch & Pinning Ceremony, a Family Weekend tradition honoring Emory's Freshman Legacies and their families. Incoming students who have at least one parent, grandparent, or sibling who graduated from Emory are invited to celebrate and be recognized for this special relationship.

Emory alumni family members will present each Legacy student with a special Legacy pin. The Legacy pins give the University a chance to express gratitude in a very tangible way to those students, parents, and family members who have chosen to continue the Emory educational tradition through each generation.

item.description:
Baker Woodlands/Source Route sculpture
Monday, October 17, 2011, 6 p.m.

Water Study is a site-specific collaborative work created by D. Patton White, Emory dance alumnus and artistic director of Beacon Dance. The work features Emory students and members of Beacon Dance. Structured as a tour of a scientific experiment, Water Study will take the audience on a journey through the environment of the Baker Woodlands ravine where they will encounter not only the scientists, but the subjects of the experiment. What will happen when the subjects begin to respond in completely unanticipated ways?

PLEASE NOTE: The Arts at Emory Box Office is closed on the weekends. Calls made on Saturday October 15th, or Sunday October 16th for weekend reservations, should be directed to Beacon Dance at 404.377.2929.

item.title: Carlos Reads Book Club
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Board Room
Monday, October 17, 2011, 7:30 – 9 p.m.

Robert Graves’ two novels, "I Claudius" and "Claudius the God" paint a compelling portrait of Rome’s first imperial dynasty, the Julio-Claudians. Meticulously based on ancient authors such as Tacitus and Suetonius, the novels reveal Graves’ expert training in Classics at Oxford. But how accurate is Graves’s depiction? Dr. Eric Varner, Associate Professor of Art History and Classics, will lead readers in an investigation not just of the novels themselves, but of what art historical and archaeological evidence might also reveal about the hidden lives of Rome’s First Family. Fee, which includes the cost of both books: $50 for Museum members; $75 for non-members.

item.title: Faculty Within Your Reach: Atlanta
item.description:
Tuesday, October 18, 2011, 6:30 – 8:30 p.m.

Faculty Within Your Reach: Atlanta
"Why History Matters"

Co-hosted with the Emory University Emeritus College

featuring

Patrick Allitt
Deborah Lipstadt
Rosemary Magee 82PhD, Moderator


"History must not be treated as something set off by itself," said Teddy Roosevelt in 1912.

In the work of Emory historians Patrick Allitt and Deborah Lipstadt , history is shown to be a living presence that infuses every moment of our contemporary existence. Patrick Allitt (Cahoon Family Professor of American History) frequently adds his voice to timely national conversations, providing a historical context and a sparkling wit.

He specializes in American, religious, and environmental history, and is the author of several award-winning books, including I'm the Teacher, You're the Student: A Semester in the University Classroom (2004) and The Conservatives: Ideas and Personalities Throughout American History (2009).

In 2000, Deborah Lipstadt (Dorot Professor of Modern Jewish History and Holocaust) made international headlines and achieved a moral victory for historians everywhere when she obtained a judgment against David Irving, a British writer and Holocaust denier, who claimed that she had libeled him in her 1993 book, Denying the Holocaust. She is the leading figure on Jewish history, and her new book, The Eichmann Trial (2011), is receiving widespread recognition and stellar reviews.

Rosemary Magee 82PhD has experienced Emory as a student, alumna, staff member, faculty member, and now as an administrator. Since 2005, she has served as vice president and secretary of the University, and is one of Emory's leading voices.


Tuesday, October 18

"Why History Matters"

6:30-7:30 p.m.: Networking and hors d'oeuvres reception
7:30-8:30 p.m.: Conversation with Patrick Allitt and Deborah Lipstadt,
moderated by Rosemary Magee 82PhD

at the Miller-Ward Alumni House
815 Houston Mill Road NE
Atlanta, GA 30329

Registration is $15 and includes hors d'oeuvres and beverages. Young Alumni (undergraduate alumni who are 10 years out or less and graduate alumni who are five years out or less) are eligible for a discounted price of $10.

More info: www.alumniconnections.com…

item.title: Film: Land of the Pharaohs
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Tuesday, October 18, 2011, 7:30 – 9:30 p.m.

A young Joan Collins plays the greedy second wife of the Old Kingdom pharaoh Khufu in "Land of the Pharaohs," directed by Howard Hawkes from a screenplay by William Faulkner. Shot on location in Egypt in 1955, the extravagant Hollywood epic used some 10,000 extras for scenes of the construction of the Khufu’s Great Pyramid. (106 min.) Dr. Matthew Bernstein, Chair of Emory’s Film Studies Department, will introduce this cult classic.

View the original trailer for the film by clicking on the link below.

Emory Event Topic: Arts
More info: www.tcm.com…

item.title: "Chinatown," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 208
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, October 19, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Roman Polanski; Paramount, 1974) (1.85:1, 140 min.) Produced by Robert Evans; written by Robert Towne; cinematography John Alonzo (& Stanley Cortez); music by Jerry Goldsmith; starring Jack Nicholson, Faye Dunaway, John Huston, Roman Polanski.

This Raymond Chandler-inspired "neo-noir" about civic corruption in 1930s Los Angeles is about as perfect a film as Hollywood has ever made. Under Polish émigré Roman Polanski's carefully modulated direction Jack Nicholson, Faye Dunaway and John Huston—himself the director of The Maltese Falcon, on many lists as the very first film noir—turned in some of the most memorable performances of their extraordinary careers. Jerry Goldsmith's haunting, evocative score—written and recorded in ten days—is ranked by the American Film Institute as one of the ten greatest scores of all time. Chinatown received a total of 11 Academy Award nominations, but only one win—for Robert Towne's original screenplay. It too is widely considered one of the best in Hollywood’s history. In 1991 the film was selected by the Library of Congress for inclusion on the National Film Registry. It looks to be Roman Polanski's last American film.

Water 2011-2012

item.title: Distinguished Alumnus Lecture: Harrison Dillon 93C
item.description:
Goizueta Business School, Room 201, 1300 Clifton Road, Atlanta, GA 30322
Thursday, October 20, 2011, 4 – 6:30 p.m.

Distinguished Alumnus Lecture
Harrison Dillon 93C, co-Founder, President, and Chief Technology Officer of
Solazyme, Inc.

“Renewable Oil Production: From Algae to Oil”

Thursday, October 20th

4:00 p.m. Lecture, room 201, Goizueta Business School
5:00 p.m. Reception, room 500, Goizueta Business School

Cost: Free

Sponsored by the Emory Office of Sustainability Initiatives and the
Emory Alumni Association


About the speaker
Solazyme traces its early beginnings to Emory University, where Harrison Dillon and Jonathan Wolfson met as freshmen on the first day of school. They began Solazyme in Harrison’s Palo Alto garage at a time when few in Silicon Valley had heard of the concept of biofuels. Dr. Dillon has guided the company’s renewable oil production technology development through numerous phases. In 2010 he was the highest ranked scientist in Biofuels Digest’s “Top 100 People to Know in Bioenergy.” He is an inventor on over 30 of Solazyme’s patents and patent applications. He received his B.S. from Emory University and received a Ph.D. in Genetics from the University of Utah. Dr. Dillon went on to manage the biotechnology patent portfolio of the University of Utah in the University’s Technology Transfer Office. Dr. Dillon received a J.D. from Duke University School of Law and is licensed to practice before the United States Patent and Trademark Office, is a member of the State Bar of California and was an Associate in the Biotechnology Group at Townsend and Townsend and Crew. Dr. Dillon has authored articles in scientific, business, and legal journals.

More info: www.alumniconnections.com…

item.title: Lecture: Egyptian Art of the Old Kingdom
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Thursday, October 20, 2011, 7:30 – 8:30 p.m.



The Old Kingdom saw the first great flowering of ancient Egyptian art. In a lecture titled "Egyptian Art of the Old Kingdom," Dr. Gay Robins, Samuel Candler Dobbs Professor of Art History at Emory, will explore the many achievements of Egyptian artists during the period and explain the functions of the monuments commissioned by the king and his elite officials that led to the development of this unique visual culture.

Emory Event Topic: Arts

item.title: Lecture & Discussion: The Art of Insight and Communing with the Unseen
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Reception Hall
Sunday, October 23, 2011, 2 – 4:30 p.m.

In conjunction with the exhibition, "Divine Intervention: African Art and Religion," Mary (Polly) Nooter Roberts, Professor in UCLA’s Department of World Arts and Cultures, and Brendan Ozawa-de Silva, Associate Director of the Drepung Loseling Monastery in Atlanta, will discuss divination among the Luba in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and in Tibetan Buddhism.

In a lecture titled, "The Art of Insight: Mediating Spirit and Human Realms in Central African Divination," Dr. Roberts will discuss the objects and practices through which Luba diviners “see” problems and find solutions to life’s most challenging circumstances.

In a lecture titled, "Communing with the Unseen: The Role of Oracles and Divination in Tibetan Politics, Medicine, and Spirituality," Dr. Ozawa-de Silva will explain the manner of consulting an oracle or diviner, the role of the mediums and their practices, the use of subsequent rituals based on received advice, and the broader context of unseen beings in Tibetan Buddhism.

This program is being held in memory of Dr. Ivan Karp, beloved colleague, mentor, and friend.

Emory Event Topic: Arts, International, Lectures & Meetings, Religion & Ethics
Building/Room: Carlos Museum
Cost: Free
Contact Name: Priyanka Sinha
Contact Phone: 404-727-4291
Contact Email: priyanka.sinha@emory.edu
More info: carlos.emory.edu

item.title: Discussion/Book-signing: Mark Auslander
item.description:
Jones Room, Level 3, Woodruff Library
Monday, October 24, 2011, 4 – 6 p.m.



Auslander is the author of “The Accidental Slaveowner: Revisiting a Myth of Race and Finding an American Family,” a book about Catherine “Miss Kitty” Boyd and Methodist Bishop James Osgood Andrew, the first president of Emory’s board of trustees. Discussion will include the role of the Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library (MARBL) in his research, his successful efforts to track down Miss Kitty’s descendants, the effects of his research and published work on the Emory and Oxford College communities, and medical discoveries made from treating enslaved people.

item.title: McDonald Lecture Series by James Carroll–Jesus: Magician or Healer?
item.description:
Glenn Auditorium, Emory University
1660 North Decatur Road NE
Atlanta, GA 30307
Monday, October 24, 2011, 7 – 9 p.m.



Award-winning author, Boston Globe columnist and former Catholic priest James Carroll is Emory University's 2011 McDonald Family Chair on the Life and Teachings of Jesus and their Impact on Culture. In this role, he will present a series of four McDonald lectures during the fall of 2011 arranged around the theme "Jesus Against Himself: From Itinerant Galilean to Christ of God and Back Again." These lectures will discuss how the fundamentals of Christian belief in Jesus are challenged by history and criticism.

"Jesus: Magician or Healer?" is the third presentation in the four-lecture series.  How does a post-modern faith find meaning in the centrality of healing for the story of Jesus? How did Jesus come to be regarded as divine, and what is the content of that doctrine today? Can we retrieve miracle, prayer and resurrection without betraying rational and critical belief?

Photograph by Patricia Pingree.

Building/Room: Glenn Memorial UMC
Event Open To: All
Contact Name: Lauren McCrary
Contact Email: candleralum@emory.edu

Region: *Metro Atlanta*

In this role, he will present a series of four McDonald lectures during the fall of 2011 arranged around the theme "Jesus Against Himself: From Itinerant Galilean to Christ of God and Back Again." These lectures will discuss how the fundamentals of Christian belief in Jesus are challenged by history and criticism.
"Jesus: Magician or Healer?" is the third presentation in the four-lecture series. How does a post-modern faith find meaning in the centrality of healing for the story of Jesus? How did Jesus come to be regarded as divine, and what is the content of that doctrine today? Can we retrieve miracle, prayer and resurrection without betraying rational and critical belief?
Photograph by Patricia Pingree.

item.title: "The Accidental Slaveowner: Revisiting a Myth of Race and Finding an American Family" -- Conversation with the Author, Mark Auslander
item.description:
1531 Dickey Dr NE
Atlanta, GA 30322-1003
Tuesday, October 25, 2011, 12 – 1 p.m.

Join us for a program on "Methodism, Slavery and Freedom: African American Memories of the 1844 Schism."

Dr. Mark Auslander (Central Washington University) will discuss the research leading to his new book, "The Accidental Slaveowner: Revisiting a Myth of Race and Finding an American Family?" (University of Georgia Press, 2011). What possibilities for reconciliation and productive dialogue have emerged through revisiting this oft-told story of race and power, and through the long search for Miss Kitty's descendants?

In 1844, the slave-owning status of Methodist Bishop James Osgood Andrew, first president of Emory College's board of trustees, tore apart the Methodist Episcopal Church, leading to the establishment of separate northern and southern churches. In retrospect, the schism has been understood as the first unraveling of the "mystic chords of union," that bound together the United States, helping precipitate the march towards Civil War. Prior accounts have emphasized the leading white participants, north and south, in this epic contest over slavery, freedom, and faith. In this presentation, former Emory faculty member Mark Auslander re-examines this historic struggle with attention to the complex experiences of the enslaved persons owned by Bishop Andrew, with special attention to the life and legacy of the enslaved woman Miss Kitty (Catherine Andrew Boyd), whose precise relationship with the Bishop has long been debated. How has her story been told, retold, and struggled over across the past 160 years?

To learn more about The Accidental Slaveowner, please see:

theaccidentalslaveowner.com

Speaker/Presenter: Mark Auslander
Event Open To: All
Building/Room: CST 102 (The Commons)

item.title: Halle Speaker Series: Faqir Syed Asif Hussain
item.description:
Winship Ballroom, Dobbs University Center
Tuesday, October 25, 2011, 1 – 2:45 p.m.

As part of the Halle Speaker Series, Faqir Syed Asif Hussain, consul general for the consulate general of Pakistan in New York, will discuss Pakistan-U.S. relations on Tuesday, Oct. 25.

This event is free and open to the public, but guests must register here by Monday, Oct. 24.

Before arriving in New York, Hussain was the minister for political affairs at the Embassy of Pakistan in Washington, D.C.

He first joined Pakistan’s diplomatic service in 1987 and in addition to posts in Islamabad, Hussain has held diplomatic assignments in Egypt, Bahrain, Bangladesh, and at the Pakistan Mission to the United Nations in New York. While at the UN, he served as vice chair of the UN committee on the peaceful settlement of disputes.

He has also been a visiting faculty member at the National Institute of Public Administration in Lahore, the Police Academy in Islamabad, and the Pakistan Air Force War College in Karachi.

item.title: Free Poetry Reading with D.A. Powell
item.description:
Jones Room, Level 3, Woodruff Library
Wednesday, October 26, 2011, 6 – 7:30 p.m.

Award-winning poet D.A. Powell will read and sign books Wednesday, Oct. 26 at 6 p.m. in the Jones Room at the Woodruff Library on the Emory University campus.

Born in Albany, Georgia, Powell writes poetry with subjects ranging from movies, music, art, and other aspects of modern culture to the AIDS epidemic. Powell's first three collections of poetry, "Tea," "Lunch," and "Cocktails," are viewed as a trilogy on the AIDS epidemic. His fourth book, "Chronic," received the Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award and was nominated for a National Book Critics Circle Award. His fifth book is due out in February 2012.

Books and a limited-edition broadside will be available for sale and signing. Light refreshments will be served after the reading.

Woodruff Library is located at 540 Asbury Circle on the Emory campus in Atlanta, 30322. Parking is available in the Fishburne Deck; visit bit.ly… for directions.

item.title: "The Blue Dahlia," Film Screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, October 26, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(George Marshall; Paramount, 1946) (1.37:1, 96 min.) Produced by John Houseman; written by Raymond Chandler; cinematography by Lionel Lindon; starring Alan Ladd, Veronica Lake, William Bendix.

Though less remembered today than Bogart and Mitchum, Alan Ladd was not only one of the earliest of noir's tough-guy anti-heroes but arguably the hardest of them all. It was his performance as an ice-cold hit man in 1942’s adaptation of Graham Greene's This Gun For Hire that turned Ladd into a star. From there Paramount moved him and his similarly cool co-star Veronica Lake on to other hardboiled writers like Dashiell Hammett (The Glass Key, 1942) and with this film, Raymond Chandler. The Blue Dahlia, Ladd's first film after his army discharge, was also Chandler’s first attempt at an original screenplay. Furious with director Marshall for shooting his own dialogue while Chandler was still trying to finish the screenplay, Chandler also fought with the Navy who felt similarly entitled to re-write his script because it featured a discharged vet. Not surprisingly Chandler spent his working hours with an open bottle next to the typewriter, something that didn't prevent the completed script from receiving an Academy Award nomination.

item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum
Tate Room and Galleries
Thursday, October 27, 2011, 5 – 7 p.m.

In a workshop titled Sacred Carving of the Ancient Egyptians, Michele Marlar, Assistant Professor in the Visual Arts Program at Morehouse College, will lead teachers on an exploration of the history and development of Egyptian hieroglyphs and some of the major texts that preserve the ancient Egyptian belief system. Dr. Marlar will look at hieroglyphic writing in the Museum’s Egyptian Galleries and in the exhibition Life and Death in the Pyramid Age: The Emory Old Kingdom Mummy.
Contact Julie Green to register, jgree09@emory.edu.
Fee: $7 for Museum members and $10 for non-members.

item.title: "Early Italian Painters and the Secret Life of Stones," Art History Endowed Lecture
item.description:
Reception Hall, Michael C. Carlos Museum
571 South Kilgo Circle
Atlanta, GA 30322
Thursday, October 27, 2011, 5:30 p.m.

Anne Dunlop, Associate Professor, History of Art at Tulane University, gives the lecture "Early Italian Painters and the Secret Life of Stones." Sponsored by the Art History Endowed Lectureship, the Michael C. Carlos Museum, and the Lila Acheson Wallace-Reader's Digest Lecture Program.

Early Italian paintings were made with gold from Africa and silvers and tins from northern and central Europe, with lapis from central Asia, and local earths and stones. This talk looks at the associations that these materials brought with them, and how the properties of pigments gave meaning to the paintings they were used to create.

Anne Dunlop is Associate Chair for Art History in the Newcomb Art Department of Tulane University. She works on the painting and culture of fourteenth- and fifteenth-century Italy. She is the author of "Painted Palaces: the Rise of Secular Art in Early Renaissance Italy" (Penn State Press, 2009), and co-editor of "Art and the Augustinian Order in Early Renaissance Italy" (Ashgate, 2007).

item.title: Mummies and Milkshakes
item.description:
Michael C. Carlos Museum, Reception Hall
Friday, October 28, 2011, 6:30 – 8:30 p.m.

The Carlos Museum and Jake’s Ice Cream present the seventh annual Mummies and Milkshakes. Visit animal and human mummies in the Egyptian galleries and the oldest true Egyptian mummy in the Western Hemisphere in the exhibition Life and Death in the Pyramid Age: The Emory Old Kingdom Mummy. Choose your favorite Jake’s Ice Cream flavor for a milkshake, and watch funny vintage mummy cartoons and the hilarious Three Stooges short, We Want Our Mummy, followed by Abbot and Costello Meet the Mummy.

item.description:
Arlington Food Assistance Center , Our Savior Lutheran Church , 825 S. Taylor Street , Arlington, VA 22204 , www.afac.org
Saturday, October 29, 2011, 12 a.m.

Emory Cares International Service Day
London, United Kingdom

Volunteer with fellow Emory alumni, students, parents, and friends on this special day of service! Alumni chapters across the US and around the world will be coming together in November to celebrate Emory Cares, a day to give back to humanity and unite in our common bond of leadership and community. Click here view images from Emory Cares 2010 projects all over the world.

Details for Emory Cares in London are still being finalized. If you're interested in helping to plan the project, please contact the project coordinator, Emily Allen 06Ox 08C (emilyallen86@gmail.com).

When registration opens, all London-area alumni will receive an announcement via email. Please update your address here to ensure you receive the announcement. For more information about Emory Cares International Service Day, check out the website, the Facebook page, and the Emory Alumni Twitter. Don't forget to join the Emory Alumni Chapter of United Kingdom Facebook group!

First Tuesday is a casual dinner with a faculty speaker and information session on the evenings of the first Tuesdays of October, November, and December 2011. item.description:
Dance Studio, Schwartz Center for Performing Arts
1700 N. Decatur Rd.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Tuesday, November 1, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

An intimate movement series uncovering the architecture, process, and findings of faculty choreography at Emory University.

This series will be an ongoing sharing of various stages of the choreographic process. Choreographers may present after performances, sharing their findings and illuminations; or while they are living the dynamic, chaotic process of crafting and discovering; or during the initial, impulsive cultivation of concepts, thoughts, images, and movement.

All events will be on Tuesday evenings at 7:30 p.m. in the Dance Studio in the Schwartz Center for Performing Arts. Free and open to the public.

item.title: Unlocking Archives and Manuscripts
item.description:
Candler School of Theology, Room 401, 1531 Dickey Drive, Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, November 2, 2011, 12 – 12:40 p.m.

Archives and manuscripts can be treasures for scholarly research, yet their potential is often completely overlooked by students in favor of secondary sources. This session will equip students with an overview necessary to begin venturing into the area of archival research. Join us as we explore what makes archives and manuscripts different, how to locate these materials, and how to incorporate them into research. Also, we will explore several opportunities for original research that are available in the Pitts Library archives and manuscript holdings.

Speaker/Presenter: Robert Presutti, Curator of Archives and Manuscripts
Series: Wednesday Workshops
Event Open To: All
Building/Room: CST 401
Contact Name: Matthew Collins
Contact Phone: 404-727-1218
Contact Email: mscolli@emory.edu
Department/Organization: Candler School of Theology Pitts Library

item.title: "Crossfire," film screening
item.description:
White Hall 205
301 Dowman Dr.
Atlanta, GA 30322
Wednesday, November 2, 2011, 7:30 p.m.

(Edward Dmytryk; RKO, 1947) (1.37:1, 86 min.) Produced by Adrian Scott & Dore Schary; cinematography by J. Roy Hunt; starring Robert Young, Robert Mitchum, Robert Ryan and Gloria Grahame. Print courtesy of the Academy Film Archive.

Crossfire was the fourth and last film from the team of Dmytryk and Scott, who first collaborated on the 1944 noir classic, Murder, My Sweet. Drawn from future director (In Cold Blood) Richard Brooks' novel The Brick Foxhole about a psychotic soldier who murders a homosexual, the Production Code’s prohibition against any reference to "sexual perversion" required that the murder’s motivation be changed. Scott and company settled on anti-Semitism. Even so, Code enforcer Joseph Breen warned the filmmakers against any "suggestion of a 'pansy' characterization." Four months after Crossfire’s release, Communists Dmytryk, Scott and eight other screenwriters dubbed "the Hollywood Ten" refused to testify before the House UnAmerican Activities Committee about Communism in Hollywood. Contempt citations were immediately issued and within 24 hours all were blacklisted from further work in the industry. Three months later, Crossfire garnered four major Academy Award nominations. Ultimately beat out for Best Picture by the similarly-themed Gentleman’s Agreement, it still took home the Best Social Film at Cannes. Two years later Dmytryk, Scott and the rest of the 'ten' went to jail.

Department/Organization: Film Studies
Type of Art: Film - Screenings, Lectures, & Events
Event Open To: All
Venue: Room 205
Building/Room: White Hall
Cost: Free
Contact Phone: 404-727-6761
More info: arts.emory.edu

item.title: GALA Planning Meetings
item.description:
Miller-Ward Alumni House Miller Room (2nd floor), 815 Houston Mill Road, Atlanta, GA 30329
Tuesday, November 8, 2011, 6 – 8 p.m.

Get involved with planning GALA events and programs! GALA meets the second Tuesday of every month from 6:00-8:00 p.m. at the Miller-Ward Alumni House to discuss upcoming GALA activities.

For those unable to attend, you can conference call into the meetings by dialing 1-877-278-8686 and entering the pin# 885565.

Meeting dates:


August 16, 6:00 - 8:00 pm, MWAH
September 13, 6:00 - 8:00 pm, MWAH
October 11, 6:00 - 8:00 pm, MWAH
November 8, 6:00 - 8:00 pm, MWAH

All are welcome to attend. We hope to see you there!

More info: www.alumniconnections.com…

item.title: “Our Environmental Destiny” Public Lecture with Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
item.description:
Glenn Memorial Auditorium
1660 North Decatur Road NE
Atlanta, GA
Wednesday, November 9, 2011, 7 – 8 p.m.

Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. will discuss the role that natural resources play in our work, our health, and our identity as Americans. A world-renowned environmentalist and humanitarian, Mr. Kennedy will remind us that we have a social responsibility to protect and preserve our planet for future generations. More than an advocate for the environment, Kennedy is an architect and agent of change. From solar energy to wind power and more, he shows how it is truly possible to become energy independent while making the world a better place.

$10 for general public, free for Emory University students, faculty, and staff

Tickets are required for event.

More info: lilliancartercenter.eventbrite.com

item.title: Gallery Talk with Kevin Young: Shadows of the Sun exhibition
item.description:
Schatten Gallery, Level 3, Woodruff Library
Wednesday, November 16, 2011, 6 – 7 p.m.

Join curator Kevin Young on a tour through Paris in the 1920s and "Shadows of the Sun: The Crosbys, the Black Sun Press, and the Lost Generation." Black Sun owners Henry and Caresse Crosby, their dedication to their small boutique press, and their friendships with writers Ernest Hemingway, D.H. Lawrence, James Joyce, Hart Crane and others are detailed in the exhibition.

Emory Event Topic: Arts
Department/Organization: MARBL-Manuscript Archives & Rare Book Library
Speaker/Presenter: Kevin Young
Event Open To: All
Venue: Schatten Gallery
Building/Room: Robert W. Woodruff Library
Cost: Free and open to the public
Contact Name: Maureen McGavin
Contact Email: mmcgavi@emory.edu
More info: bit.ly…

item.description:
Glenn Memorial Auditorium
Druid HIlls Campus
Wednesday, December 7, 2011, 11 a.m. – 12 p.m.

President James W. Wagner, joined by faculty in regalia, gives the 175th anniversary address, including recognition of the 175 Emory history makers.

item.title: First Tuesday at Candler
item.description:
Candler School of Theology, Suite 517, 1531 Dickey Dr., Atlanta, GA 30322
Tuesday, February 7, 2012, 6:30 – 8:30 p.m.

Spend an evening with us this Spring 2012 at one of our First Tuesday at Candler events for prospective students. First Tuesday is a casual dinner with a faculty speaker and information session on the evenings of the first Tuesdays of February, March and April 2012. The events will feature a welcome by Dean Jan Love and a talk by a distinguished member of the faculty. Participants will be able to visit with current Candler students and members of the admissions team. We will have activities for kids during the informational portion of the evening, so bring the whole family! Choose from the following programs:

Dr. Anne Burkholder, Associate Dean of Methodist Studies and Professor in the Practice of Ecclesiology and Church Leadership
"Conservative vs. Liberal: Why These Categories Don't Work For Us Anymore

Emory Event Topic: Special Event
Department/Organization: Candler School of Theology Admissions
Building/Room: CST 517
Event Open To: All
Registration Link: candler.emory.edu…
Contact Name: Rich Landers
Contact Phone: 404.727.6326
Contact Email: candleradmissions@emory.edu
